section.p:
The default form of the preposition is simply mu –
mu thaigh about a house
mu aislingean about dreams
mu Nirribhidh about Norway
mu thrì làithean about three days

When the immediately following word is a singular form of the definite article, the linking form mun is used –
mun an taigh about the house, rather than mu an taigh
mun a’ bhaile about the town, rather than mu a’ bhaile But –
mu na h-aislingean about the dreams, rather than mun na h-aislingean
Note that mun an and mun a’ often reduce to just mun – mun taigh, mun bhaile.

Fused forms are sometimes found when the immediately following word is a possessive determiner –
mu mo thaigh about my house ≈ mum thaigh
mu do bhaile about your town ≈ mud bhaile
mu a h-òran about her song ≈ mu h-òran
mu a chraoibh about his tree ≈ mu chraoibh
mu ar n-achadh about our field ≈ mar n-achadh
mu ur leapannan about your beds ≈ mur leapannan
mu an taighean about their houses ≈ mun taighean
mu am baile about their town ≈ mum baile
Note that these fused forms are rather awkward and sometimes ambiguous and hence are best avoided in writing nowadays.

Conjugated prepositions are used in place of mu mi, mu thu, ... , mu iad –
umam about me
umad about you
uimpe about her/it
uime about him/it
umainn about us
umaibh about you
umpa about them

There are also emphatic forms (cf. mu mise, mu thusa, ... , mu iadsan) –
umamsa about me
umadsa about you
uimpese about her/it
uimesan about him/it
umainne about us
umaibhse about you
umpasan about them
Note that the form uimesan breaks the ‘slender-to-slender, broad-to-broad’ spelling rule, and hence is sometimes found written with a hyphen – uime-san.

Finally, there are also reflexive forms (cf. mu mi fhìn, mu thu fhèin, ... , mu iad fhèin) –
umam fhìn about myself
umad fhèin about yourself
uimpe fhèin about herself/itself
uime fhèin about himself/itself
umainn fhìn about ourselves
umaibh fhèin about yourselves
umpa fhèin about themselves
